(2015) Sugarplum Fairies - Sunday, Suddenly



Review:
The folk noir on Sugarplum Fairiesâ€™ new album Sunday Suddenly comes with one foot in a European sidewalk cafÃ© and the other boot on a dusty road in the vast American West. In either locale, Vienna-born, L.A.-based singer-songwriter Silvia Ryder sounds appropriately brooding; espresso in hand, journal at her side, she could be gazing at anonymous passers-by on a Parisian sidewalk nor a cactus-dotted horizon, either one.
Sunday Suddenly is the seventh Sugarplum Fairies full-length, and the second since Ryder and collaborator Ben Bohm split in 2013. Produced by Marlon Rabenreither of Gold Star/the Sister Ruby Band (he produced Lael Nealeâ€™s â€œIâ€™ll Be Your Manâ€), the album features guest turns from L.A.-based Scotsman Charlie Clark (gently in the background on â€œBlues Run the Gameâ€), RT Valine of RT Nâ€™ the 44s (dueting with True Grit on â€œDream Number Threeâ€) and Taylor Borsuk of Skin & Bones (joining in evocatively on the last call-worthy â€œBlueâ€). The albumâ€™s Fellini-gone-West moment comes on the gauzy â€œPale Vellum Dreams,â€ which recalls Kendra Smith meets the Dandy Warhols.
